raw_comment:
Notice:
Admission spikes for the top 0.1% regardless of a student's legacy status. 
For poorer students, the admission gap between legacy and non-legacy applicants is fairly stable. For applicants above the fiftieth percentile, legacy students have a much higher advantage. 
Admittance of non-legacy students dips after the 70th percentile and spikes again around 99.
Non-legacy students have the best admittance if either above the 90th percentile or below the 50th: upper/middle-class students don't have great chances unless legacy. probably because neither in need of financial aid nor willing/able to fund programs. 
Wonder: 
Other than test scores, legacy status, and parental income, what factors are considered? How would extracurriculars, GPA, and other factors change this? - many schools no longer consider test scores (especially elite colleges). 
Relate: 
As a high school student, I am fairly anxious about college admissions. I've seen a lot of people with really impressive applications who weren't accepted into the schools they wanted. I know someone personally who graduated high school in 2022 with good grades, great test scores, and a year in an exchange program and still got in almost nowhere she applied. 
Headline: 
No Legacy, No Money, No Luck: Bias in College Admissions
